quizzes.textContent:
[h1]PHP Syntax[/h1]

A PHP script starts with [b]<?php[/b] and ends with [b]?>[/b]: [code format="php" ][b]<?php[/b]
  // PHP code goes here
[b]?>[/b][/code]
Here is an example of a simple PHP file. The PHP script uses a built in function called "[b]echo[/b]" to output the text "Hello World!" to a web page.[code format="raw" codeId="454"]<html>
  <head>
    <title>My First PHP Page</title>
  </head>
  <body>
[b]  <?php   
    echo "Hello World!";
  ?>[/b]
  </body>
</html>[/code]
[note]PHP statements end with [b]semicolons (;)[/b].[/note]

quizzes.question: Which of the following is correct when using PHP with the script tag?
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]PHP Syntax[/h1]

Alternatively, we can include PHP in the HTML [b]<script>[/b] tag.[code format="raw" ]<html>
  <head>
    <title>My First PHP Page</title>
  </head>
  <body>
  [b]<script language="php">[/b]
    echo "Hello World!";
  [b]</script>[/b]
  </body>
</html>[/code]
[note]However, the latest version of PHP removes support for <script language="php"> tags. As such, we recommend using [b]<?php ?>[/b] exclusively.[/note]

quizzes.question: Which is the most widely recommended way to use PHP tags?
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]PHP Syntax[/h1]

You can also use the shorthand PHP tags, <? ?>, as long as they're supported by the server.[code format="php" codeId="456"]<[b]?
  echo "Hello World!";
?>[/b][/code]  
[note]However, [b]<?php ?>[/b], as the official standard, is the recommended way of defining PHP scripts.[/note]
